verses.text: These are the men who came to David at Ziklag while he was still banned from Saul son of Kish. They were among the warriors who helped him in battle.
verses.comment: Ziklag was a Philistine city given to David (1 Sam. 27:6). 'Helped him in battle' emphasizes their role as allies during his period as an outlaw.

verses.text: They were armed with bows and could use both the right and the left hand to sling stones and to shoot arrows from the bow. They were of Saul’s relatives from Benjamin.
verses.comment: 'Both the right and left hand' – ambidextrous skill was notable in ancient warfare. 'Saul’s relatives' specifies they were Benjaminites.

verses.text: The chief was Ahiezer, then Joash, sons of Shemaah of Gibeah; Jeziel and Pelet, sons of Azmaveth; Beracah, Jehu the Anathothite,
verses.comment: 'Chief' means group leader. The names and origins are transliterated closely from the Hebrew.

verses.text: Ishmaiah the Gibeonite, a mighty man among the thirty and over the thirty; Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, Jozabad the Gederathite,
verses.comment: Gibeonite refers to a city in Benjamin's tribe. 'Over the thirty' likely refers to leadership among an elite corps.

verses.text: Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, Shemariah, Shephatiah the Haruphite,
verses.comment: A list of men, likely elite warriors, with tribal/city identification.

verses.text: Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Jashobeam, the Korahites,
verses.comment: 'Korahite' refers to a Levitical clan from Korah.

verses.text: Joela and Zebadiah, sons of Jeroham of Gedor.
verses.comment: Gedor is a city in Judah. This closes the list from Benjamin’s tribe.

verses.text: Some Gadites defected to David at the stronghold in the wilderness, mighty men of valor, men trained for war, who could handle shield and spear, whose faces were like the faces of lions and who were as swift as the gazelles on the mountains.
verses.comment: "Stronghold" is likely Adullam or similar; 'faces like lions' and 'swift as gazelles' are idioms for bravery and speed.

verses.text: Ezer the chief, Obadiah the second, Eliab the third,
verses.comment: List of thirteen Gadite leaders.

verses.text: Mishmannah the fourth, Jeremiah the fifth,
Attai the sixth, Eliel the seventh,
Johanan the eighth, Elzabad the ninth,
Jeremiah the tenth, Machbannai the eleventh.
verses.comment: Finishes the Gadite leaders list. 'Machbannai' is as rendered in most manuscripts.

verses.text: These Gadites were captains of the army; the least was a match for a hundred men, and the greatest for a thousand.
verses.comment: 'Captains of the army' emphasizes their rank. Numbers are likely hyperbolic or idiomatic.

verses.text: These are the men who crossed the Jordan in the first month when it was overflowing all its banks, and they put to flight all who lived in the valleys to the east and to the west.
verses.comment: 'First month' is Nisan/March–April. 'Overflowing' refers to spring floods. The feat emphasizes their bravery.

verses.text: Some men from Benjamin and Judah also came to David at the stronghold.
verses.comment: 'Stronghold' here could be Adullam or En Gedi. The tribes are David's own (Judah) and Saul's (Benjamin).

verses.text: David went out to meet them and said to them, "If you have come in peace to help me, my heart will be united with you. But if you have come to betray me to my enemies, though I have done no wrong, may the God of our ancestors see it and judge."
verses.comment: David's speech highlights loyalty and the invocation of God as judge.

verses.text: Then the Spirit came upon Amasai, chief of the thirty, and he said, "We are yours, David! We are with you, son of Jesse! Peace, peace to you, and to those who help you, for your God helps you." So David received them and made them leaders of his troops.
verses.comment: 'Spirit came upon' refers to inspiration/prophecy. 'Chief of the thirty' may mean chief leader of thirty elite warriors.

verses.text: Some of the Manassites defected to David when he came with the Philistines to battle against Saul. But they did not help the Philistines, for the lords of the Philistines sent him away after deliberation, saying, "He may defect to his master Saul and it will endanger our heads."
verses.comment: Describes David's position in the Philistine army and their suspicion.

verses.text: As he went to Ziklag, these Manassites joined him: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai, commanders of thousands in Manasseh.
verses.comment: 'Commanders of thousands' – standard military title.

verses.text: They helped David against the band of raiders, for they were all mighty men of valor and were commanders in the army.
verses.comment: 'Band of raiders' refers to Amalekites who plundered Ziklag.

verses.text: For day by day, people came to David to help him, until there was a great army, like the army of God.
verses.comment: 'Army of God' is an idiom for a vast, impressive force.

verses.text: These are the numbers of the heads of those armed for war, who came to David at Hebron to turn over Saul’s kingdom to him, as the LORD had promised:
verses.comment: 'As the LORD had promised' refers to God's prophecy to David's kingship.

verses.text: From Judah, carrying shield and spear: 6,800 armed for war.
verses.comment: Each following verse lists tribal contributions.

verses.text: From Simeon, mighty men of valor for war: 7,100.
From Levi: 4,600.
Jehoiada, the leader of the house of Aaron, and with him 3,700;
verses.comment: Leads for the priestly tribe.

verses.text: Zadok, a young mighty man of valor, and twenty-two leaders from his father’s house.
verses.comment: Zadok later becomes chief priest.

verses.text: From Benjamin, Saul’s relatives: 3,000. Even up to that time, most of them had kept their loyalty to the house of Saul.
verses.comment: Benjamin's small contingent due to their loyalty to Saul.

verses.text: From Ephraim: 20,800 mighty men of valor, famous in their fathers’ families.
From the half-tribe of Manasseh: 18,000, chosen by name to come and make David king.
verses.comment: 'Chosen by name' implies hand-picked, notable men.

verses.text: From Issachar, men who understood the times and knew what Israel should do: 200 chiefs, with all their relatives under their command.
verses.comment: 'Understood the times'—known for wise leadership and discernment.

verses.text: From Zebulun, such as went out to battle, expert in war, with all weapons of war, who could order the battle array: 50,000 who could keep rank—they were not of double heart.
verses.comment: 'Not of double heart' means they were loyal/steadfast.

verses.text: From Naphtali: 1,000 commanders, and with them, 37,000 men with shield and spear.
From Dan: 28,600 who could handle war.
verses.comment: 'Could handle war' implies skill and training.

verses.text: From Asher, men who could go out to battle, able to keep formation: 40,000.
From the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, from the other side of the Jordan, 120,000 with all kinds of weapons of war for battle.
verses.comment: 'Other side of the Jordan' means the Transjordan tribes.

verses.text: All these, men of war, equipped for the battle line, came with a whole heart to Hebron, to make David king over all Israel. And all the rest of Israel was of one mind to make David king.
verses.comment: 'Whole heart' means full commitment; unified support for David's reign.

verses.text: And they were there with David for three days, eating and drinking, for their relatives had prepared for them.
verses.comment: Describing a covenant feast celebrating David’s anointing.

verses.text: Also, their neighbors, as far as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali, were bringing food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen—abundant provisions of flour, fig cakes, raisins, wine, oil, cattle, and sheep, for there was joy in Israel.
verses.comment: 'Food' is rendered with specific items common in the original text; underscores the universal joy and hospitality.
